title: Turnover
text:
Trend of Exits
To start our understanding of employee turnover trends we are first looking at the monthly exits trended from 2018 to now and then we have calculated the year turnover rates.

We see the trend of exits (as well as yearly turnover rates) saw a significant change from pre-pandemic levels during both 2022 and 2023.
While 2025 YTD turnover is still higher than pre-pandemic levels, the average monthly levels have significantly decreased.










In order to understand more about the drivers of the increases in 2022 and 2023, we will then dig into the different characteristics of our employees.


Analysis Overview

Exits:Voluntary vs InvoluntaryTurnover rateNext Steps

Looking into the population of employees within 2022-2023 vs 2018-2022

Notes
The initial exploratory data analysis (EDA) was performed within ‘src/clean_employee.R’ which can be found within the source code.
I built “monthly_employee.R” as a function that could be called to get the active number of employees per month given a dataset like this HRIS sample. This would allow for a quick recreated of monthly view when we are testing future policy impacts.

title: Next Steps
text:
So what are our next steps from here?

Additonal Information to Capture

Would love to capture more information about exits to better track. One that would be interesting is capturing when we have ‘regrettable loss’, or better detailing what characteristics would make an exit more regettable for the organization.
Would be interesting to bring in the exit interview data to augment the analysis to dig further into employee’s decisions to leave.



Testing Hypotheses

We would want to measure the turnover after we make this policy change to determine if it had the intended affect.

Know that this would be a long feedback loop as we would want to wait at least a month before testing again.
Could utilize a chi-sqare test to test for differences.

title: Employee Characteristics
text:
This is where we will provide an analysis into the HRIS data in order to determine if we see if there are certain employee charatistics make are indicitive of whether or not an employee is more likely to leave.
This is a space where we’d be interested to tease out the difference’s between different demographics and whether or not their responses are indicitive of different behaviors.
We are looking at the following descriptors:

Deomgraphics:

Gender
Race (collapsed into -> white/non-white)

Role Details:

Full Time vs Part Time
Department
Location

Performance:

Employee Performance
Most Recent Merit

title: Overview
text:
Presentation last built on: 2025-10-13



Note from Phil
I am aiming to provide a clear and instructive analysis to Sr Leadership, mixing both written prose and visuals to provide an artifact for later viewing as well as a tool to center the conversation for this decision. I will start with the high level recommendation and then provide the steps for how we get there, knowing that depending on the leader’s availability, sometimes there is only time for the analysis and sometimes it’s desired to know how we got to the answer.
I have intentionally designed this to be a code driven analysis in order to ensure that both the analysis is reproducible as well as that the code is reusable. It has been a common occurance for me where I have provided an analysis, we’ve made a decision and then a year later we want to evaluate the results. By this solution being code based, we are able to quickly recreate the analysis and update with the necessary data without having to wonder if some data was omited due to outliers or if we intentionally just focused on a specific population.
Because this presentation is meant for Sr Leadership I have intentionally removed most code, except for situations where it would be instructive or in more of of the detailed appendix. If you would like to review the code, please visit the code repository on Github by clicking on the icon on the top right and navigating to the “Source Code” link.
Thanks for following along!
-phil walker


Analysis Overview

Problem Statement:OutcomesData SouresAssumptions


Below is the provided problem statement. This is what we will use as our driving focus for this analysis.

You are a Senior HR Data & Insights Consultant and have been asked to assist senior HR leadership make a decision regarding a planned policy change.



Senior leadership is concerned with the on-going impact the pandemic and “Great Resignation” has had on the workforce. There is a pervasive belief that turnover has been steadily on the rise over the past five years, and recent high-profile terminations among some of the organization’s top performers have raised questions regarding the organization’s retention strategy.
Senior leaders believe compensation is driving turnover and have proposed implementing an across the board annual raise of 6% at the start of next year to counteract the effect of inflation.
You have one week to clean, review, and analyze the provided data to help senior leadership understand the current turnover landscape, the cost of their proposal, and whether the proposed retention strategy will have the desired impact.




The following are the outcomes of this analysis. Also provided are the links to the locations of the outcomes.

Detailing the current turnover rate -> Turnover Analysis

tdlr; 2022 and 2023 saw significantly higher turnover, but it’s been returning back to pre-pandemic rates.

Detailing if there are certain groups with higher turnover
Determine if the higher turnover is correlated to the responses in the employee engagement survey
Would a 6% raise even impact the cost of living due to inflation?



For this analysis we will be using the following data sources:

HRIS Data - Employee tenure and Demographics

Provided by employeer

HRIS Data - Employee Survey Response

Provided by employeer

BLS - JOLTS
BLA - Inflation (Consumer Price Index)
Michigan Job
Michigan Workforce Reports
Nashville Workforce Reports




Calculations

Average Employees Per Month: Uses the # at the start of the month
Turnover = # Resigned/ Avg Employee

We are extracting part time employees from the population as we would expect the turnover rate to be different for these populations
For this analysis we are also going to remove Temporary employees.
We recognize that there have been a large economic shift where more employees are staying at their companies, if we were to make a policy change we would want to differentiate between (and look for a causal link) between the policy and the company’s turnover.
Identify top performers as:

those with a performance rating of 4 or 5

Assuming that employees that are that employees with the effective date of the current job are _____
Jackson’s NAICS code is 524113 (designates Direct Life Insurance Carriers)

falls under the “Finance and Insurance” sector. (Sector 52)

title: Survey Responses
text:
This is where we will provide an analysis into the survey responses in order to determine if we see a correlation between survey responses and the ultimately the employee’s decision to leave the company or not
This is a space where we’d be interested to tease out the difference’s between different demographics and whether or not their responses are indicitive of different behaviors.









We see a shift in responses from more negative in 2021 -> more positive in 2025
